The seventh sun: A 
 tribal tale from 
 
 Odisha, India 
 Indian Folktale 
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Long, long ago there were seven suns in
 the sky. 
 
 
 Their rays made the earth so hot that
 human beings could not bear it. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 So, the seven brothers belonging to a 
 tribe caled the Munda decided to kil the 
 
 suns. 
 
 They shot arows at them and were able 
 
 to kil six of the suns. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The seventh sun hid behind a hil.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Now, with the suns gone, there was 
 
 darknes everywhere. 
 
 The der could not se the tigers, the 
 
 elephants bumped into tres, the rabits 
 walked over the lions and there was 
 
 confusion al around. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 To find a way out, the animals decided to
 have a meting. 
 
 
 A rabit told them about one of the seven
 suns who was stil alive and hiding
 
 behind a hil. 
 
 
 But who would be the best one to cal out
 to the sun? 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 "I wil cal out to the sun," said the lion, for 
 he was the king of the forest. 
 
 
 "Sun, sun, please do not run away from 
 us. Come back in and shine on us," 
 roared the lion. 
 
 
 But the sun did not listen to him. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The elephant caled out next. 
 
 He raised his trunk and trumpeted, "Sun,
 
 sun, please come back," but the sun did
 not listen to him. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The beautiful peacock danced and 
 pleaded, "Sun, sun, please come back," 
 
 but the sun refused to come out. 
 
 One after the other, al the animals caled 
 
 out to the sun, but he did not listen to any 
 of them. 
 
 
 Finaly, a roster ofered to cal the sun. 
 Everybody laughed. The lion was a fair 
 
 leader. He said, "The roster should be 
 alowed to try." 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The roster steped forward and gently
 crowed, "Kokodoko - ko." 
 
 
 To everyone's surprise, the sun peped
 out a litle from behind the hil.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The roster crowed again, this time a litle boldly, 
 
 "KokodoKO-KO." 
 
 The sun came up a litle higher. The roster crowed for the 
 
 third time. This time it was louder and bolder, 
 "KOKODOKO-KO." and the sun rose high and bright. 
 
 
 There was light everywhere. 
 
 
 The animals were delighted and the humans felt relieved. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The animals asked the human beings not
 to kil the sun and they agred.
 
 
 Ever since that day, when the roster
 crows in the morning, the sun rises and
 
 shines in the sky.
